description.narrative: N of government officers and planner Kaupule members and NGO personnel that have increased capacity in identifying climate risks planning adaptation measures and sustain community awareness on climate chnage issues

comment.narrative:
The countrys responses to climate change risks and adaptation are ad hoc and piecemeal and not adequately supported by legislation
Planners policy makers Kaupule and vulnerable communities are unable to anticipate climate change impacts and integrate these into policy revision financial planning and decisionmaking processes

At least 200 DoE and DoA officials and planners in other government agencies DoF Education DoH DMO PWD in Tuvalu and in the islands Kaupule and 30 personnel in NGOs participating in the project TANGO NCW are able to i identify climateinduced risks in coastal areas ii prioritize and plan effective adaptation measures on the basis of participatory assessments and iii sustain community awareness of climate changerelated risk issues

In JulyAugust 2014 a combined team from the Government including Agriculture Lands Public Works Education Solid Waste Agency of Tuvalu SWAT and nongovernment institutions including Tuvalu Association of NGOs TANGO Red Cross and Integrated Island Biodiversity IIB visited 4 schools Nauti Primary School Seventh Day Adventist Primary School Fetuvalu High School and Motufoua Form Seven Programme and the 8 island communities on the Capital Funafuti Nui Nanumaga Nanumea Niutao Vaitupu Nukulaelae and Nukufetau to disseminate climate risk information to school children and island communities During these visits a total of 578 people 306 males and 272 females received a training on climate risk information and its potential impact on food and water security and coastal erosion In addition 1733 school children also received similar information through presentations and quiz

description.narrative: Outcome 1 Enhanced capacity of public administration Island Kaupules communities and NGOs with policy support to plan for and respond to climate change risks in coastal areas and settlements
N of schools capacitated to conduct climatechange related education programmes

comment.narrative: Environmental issues are integrated into school curricula but very limited on climate change topics
By the end of the Project the 10 Primary Schools and 2 Secondary Schools functioning in Tuvalu are capacitated to conduct climate change related education programme

A Curriculum Development officer was funded by the NAPA 1 project to attend the Sandwatch workshop in New Caledonia in December 2014 The outcome of the workshop was a training workshop for teachers around the country in April 2015 The training was facilitated by the Curriculum Development Officer who attended the Sandwatch training The outcome of the training of teachers is the enhancement of teachers ability to teach climate change education programmers in their schools The next step is to incorporate Climate Change topics into school curricula both at primary and secondary school level
